name: Checklists_PreFlight
shortDescription: Learn and practice essential checklists and pre-flight inspection procedures for the Cessna 172
prompt: You are teaching a student pilot the critical importance of checklists and proper pre-flight inspection procedures in a Cessna 172. Emphasize that checklists are not just items to check off - they are a systematic approach to ensure safety. Cover the exterior walk-around inspection, interior checklist items, engine start procedures, and taxi checklist. Make the student understand that every flight begins on the ground with thorough preparation. This lesson takes place at Palo Alto Airport (KPAO).
openingLine: Today we will learn one of the most important habits in aviation: using checklists. Ready to become a disciplined, safe pilot?

phases.name: Brief
phases.prompt: Brief the student on the critical importance of checklists in aviation. Explain that checklists prevent mistakes, ensure nothing is forgotten, and are used by pilots at every level - from students to airline captains. Today they will learn the exterior pre-flight inspection and the key interior checklists: Before Start, Engine Start, Before Taxi, and Taxi.
steps: Explain why checklists are essential for safety
Describe the types of checklists they will learn today
Emphasize the flow: exterior inspection first, then interior checklists
Set expectations: this will take time at first, but will become second nature
goals: Student understands the purpose of checklists
Student knows they will learn exterior and interior procedures
Student appreciates that thorough preparation prevents accidents

phases.name: Exterior_Walkaround
phases.prompt: Guide the student through a complete exterior pre-flight inspection of the Cessna 172. Use a systematic pattern: start at the cabin door, go around the left wing, continue to the nose, right wing, and return to the cabin. Check for damage, loose parts, fuel quantity and contamination, oil level, control surfaces, tires, and general condition. Explain what you are looking for at each step and why.
steps: Start at the cabin door - check general condition
Left wing: check flaps, aileron, fuel cap and quantity, pitot tube, landing light, tie-down, tires
Tail section: check rudder, elevator, trim tab, tie-down, beacon light
Right wing: check flaps, aileron, fuel cap and quantity, stall warning, tie-down, strut, tires
Nose: check propeller for nicks, spinner, air intake, nose gear, oil level and door security
Remove control locks and tie-downs
Check for water in fuel with fuel sampler (sump both tanks and gascolator)
goals: Student performs a complete walk-around inspection
Student knows what to look for at each inspection point
Student understands the importance of checking fuel for water contamination
Student can explain why each check matters for safety
commonErrors: Rushing through the inspection without really looking
Forgetting to check fuel for water contamination
Not checking oil level or checking it incorrectly
Skipping control surface checks
Forgetting to remove control locks or tie-downs

phases.name: Interior_Before_Start
phases.prompt: Teach the Before Start checklist. This prepares the cockpit before engine start. Cover: preflight inspection complete, seats adjusted and belts fastened, fuel selector on both, fuel shutoff valve in, avionics master off, all switches off, circuit breakers in, and controls free and correct.
steps: Confirm preflight inspection is complete
Adjust and lock pilot seat, fasten seatbelts
Set fuel selector to BOTH
Ensure fuel shutoff valve is IN
Turn avionics master OFF (protects electronics during start)
Verify all electrical switches are OFF
Check all circuit breakers are IN
Test flight controls for free and correct movement
Set flaps to takeoff position (usually 0 or 10 degrees)
goals: Student completes Before Start checklist systematically
Student understands why avionics are off during engine start
Student verifies controls move freely and correctly
Student develops habit of following checklist order
commonErrors: Starting engine with avionics master on
Not checking that controls move freely
Forgetting to set fuel selector to BOTH
Not securing seat properly before start

phases.name: Engine_Start
phases.prompt: Guide the student through the engine start procedure. Emphasize safety: area clear, brakes set, throttle cracked, mixture rich, propeller area clear with verbal announcement. Cover the full sequence: master on, beacon on, prime if needed, announce clear prop, turn key to start, verify oil pressure, and complete after-start items.
steps: Set parking brake
Open throttle approximately 1/4 inch
Set mixture to full rich
Turn master switch ON
Turn beacon light ON (warns people engine is about to start)
Prime engine if cold (2-3 strokes)
Announce CLEAR PROP loudly and check propeller area
Turn ignition key to START (release when engine catches)
Verify oil pressure rises within 30 seconds (critical check)
Adjust throttle to approximately 1000 RPM
Check alternator is charging (ammeter shows positive)
Turn on avionics master after engine is running smoothly
goals: Student performs engine start safely and correctly
Student always announces CLEAR PROP
Student verifies oil pressure immediately after start
Student understands the importance of each step in the sequence
commonErrors: Not announcing CLEAR PROP
Forgetting to check oil pressure rise
Starting with mixture lean
Not using enough prime on cold engine or over-priming on warm engine
Holding starter too long

phases.name: Before_Taxi_Checklist
phases.prompt: Teach the Before Taxi checklist. Now that the engine is running, prepare for taxi. Cover: flight instruments set, radios set and tested, transponder set to assigned code, ATIS or AWOS obtained, altimeter set, heading indicator set to compass, and taxi clearance obtained if at towered airport.
steps: Set and check flight instruments (attitude indicator, heading indicator, altimeter)
Tune radios (KPAO tower frequency or CTAF if non-towered)
Set transponder to assigned squawk code or 1200
Obtain ATIS or AWOS weather information
Set altimeter to current setting
Set heading indicator to match magnetic compass
Test brakes by gently applying pressure
If towered airport, call for taxi clearance with your location and intentions
Review taxi route if unfamiliar with airport
goals: Student completes all before taxi items
Student knows how to obtain weather and set altimeter
Student can properly request taxi clearance
Student tests brakes before moving
commonErrors: Forgetting to get ATIS or AWOS
Not setting altimeter correctly
Starting to taxi without clearance at towered airport
Not testing brakes before taxi

phases.name: Taxi_Checklist
phases.prompt: Teach proper taxi procedures and the Taxi checklist. Cover: flight controls checked for wind, taxi at safe speed (fast walk pace), use of rudder pedals for steering and brakes, looking outside continuously, and completing the run-up checklist location planning.
steps: Position flight controls correctly for wind conditions
Release parking brake
Add power smoothly to begin taxi
Maintain safe taxi speed (walking pace, slower in congested areas)
Steer with rudder pedals (not the yoke)
Practice using brakes gently
Keep head up and look outside constantly for other aircraft and obstacles
Follow taxi lines and signs
Plan where to perform run-up (usually near departure end of runway)
goals: Student taxis at safe speed with good directional control
Student looks outside and maintains situational awareness
Student uses proper control positions for wind
Student communicates position on taxiway if at towered airport
commonErrors: Taxiing too fast
Not looking outside enough
Using nose wheel steering instead of rudder pedals (in sim context)
Forgetting to position controls for wind
Getting lost on the taxiway

phases.name: Debrief
phases.prompt: Review all the checklists and procedures covered today. Quiz the student on key safety items. Emphasize that checklists are not optional - they save lives. Answer any questions and encourage the student to practice these flows until they become automatic. Preview that next lesson will involve actual flight with these checklists.
steps: Ask student to explain the exterior walk-around sequence
Quiz on critical items: CLEAR PROP, oil pressure check, brake test
Discuss why we always use checklists, even when experienced
Answer any remaining questions
Encourage practice and study of checklists before next flight
Preview next lesson: basic flight controls in the air
goals: Student can recall the major checklist phases
Student understands critical safety checks
Student is committed to always using checklists
Student feels prepared for next lesson
